content:
The Act may be cited as the "Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission Act". Congress finds that Frederick Douglass, born into slavery in 1818, rose to prominence through determination and eloquence. He was an abolitionist, human rights activist, and renowned orator who escaped slavery and became internationally known. Frederick Douglass escaped slavery, became a prominent advocate for liberty, served in the national government, and played a key role in recruiting African-American troops for the Union Army during the Civil War. He later focused on integrating African-Americans into American society after the abolition of slavery. Frederick Douglass dedicated his life to achieving justice for all Americans, serving as an advisor to Presidents and holding various government positions. He was appointed by multiple Presidents and envisioned an inclusive America free of discrimination. Frederick Douglass lived in the District of Columbia for 23 years as a free man and his home, Cedar Hill, is now a National Historic Site. The statue of Douglass in the US Capitol was a gift from the residents of DC. Studying Douglass's life can benefit all Americans as he dedicated his life to ensuring freedom and equality for future generations. The bicentennial anniversary of Frederick Douglass's birth in 2018 is a significant milestone, calling for the establishment of a commission to plan and execute fitting programs to honor his legacy. The Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission is established to plan and carry out programs to honor Frederick Douglass on the bicentennial anniversary of his birth. The Commission will recommend fitting programs to Congress and determine the appropriate entities in the Federal Government to execute them. The Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the President and Governors of Maryland, Massachusetts, and New York. The Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the President, Mayor of the District of Columbia, Speaker of the House of Representatives, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leaders of both the House and Senate. Qualified citizens must have a dedication to educating others about the United States. The Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission requires members to have a dedication to educating others about historical figures and events, particularly Frederick Douglass. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the enactment of the Act, and members serve for life. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission members serve without pay and receive travel expenses. Six members constitute a quorum, with the Commission selecting a Chair. Meetings are held at the Chair's call, with periodic meetings in Rochester, New York. The Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission members serve without pay and receive travel expenses. The Commission may appoint a Director and additional personnel as needed. The Director may be appointed without following certain civil service laws, while the staff must adhere to these laws for appointments and pay. The Commission may appoint a Director and additional personnel as needed, with the Director being appointed without following certain civil service laws. The staff must adhere to these laws for appointments and pay, specifically in subchapter III of chapter 53 of that title. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission under this Act has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies and use the US mails like other government entities. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. It is also allowed to solicit, accept, and use gifts for carrying out its duties. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

The Commission must submit an initial report to Congress by August 1, 2018, with recommendations. A final report is due by June 1, 2019, detailing activities, funds, and any other relevant information.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end 30 days after submitting the final report.
